Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Cloud System Evolution in the Trades
Award.AbstractNarration:
This study aims to understand the evolution of the boundary layer cloud, aerosol and thermodynamic structures along trajectories within the north-Pacific trade-winds using observations from the NSF/NCAR Gulfstream V (HIAPER). This effort includes characterization of the cloud, precipitation and aerosol fields in the stratocumulus (Sc) and the fair-weather cumulus (Cu) regimes within the subtropical easterlies over the northern Pacific and the use of Large Eddy Simulation (LES) models to simulate the cloud evolution along the trajectories sampled.

Intellectual merit:
These characterizations along trajectories will be designed to aid in our understanding and simulation of the transition between the two convective regimes - a critical factor in the climate system. LES models have become a robust tool for Lagrangian simulations of subtropical cloudiness transitions, but there are few good datasets for comprehensively testing these simulations. In particular, adequate observations of the coupled evolution of aerosol, cloud droplet number concentration and precipitation during such transitions are lacked. Thus, the observing strategy will be to sample aerosol, cloud, precipitation, and boundary layer properties upwind from the transition zone over the North Pacific and to resample these areas two and four days later. This Lagrangian approach is designed to minimize uncertainties in the large-scale forcing due to horizontal advection in the lower troposphere as air masses move from colder to warmer sea surface temperatures and thus facilitate model simulations and isolate critical physical processes.

Two key elements of the observing system will be a newly developed HIAPER Cloud Radar (HCR) and the HIAPER High Spectral Resolution Lidar (HSRL). The HCR will be used to provide cloud and precipitation characteristics. The HSRL will provide cloud boundaries and aerosol characteristics when viewing non-cloudy volumes. A full suite of probes on the aircraft will be used for in situ measurements of aerosol, cloud, precipitation, and turbulence properties. Two modes of operations will be made on flights between the west coast of California and Hawaii. One will include remote sensing (mapping) of the clouds and boundary layer from flight levels above the boundary layer made upstream and downstream from the Sc to Cu transition zone. The other will involve detailed profiling in the subcloud and cloud layer in two or three selected areas upstream and downstream from the transition zone to make detailed in situ measurements of aerosols, clouds, precipitation, and turbulence. On the surveying legs dropsondes will be used to obtain the thermodynamic and wind structure in and above the boundary layer. Several flight sequences are planned for the June-July 2015 timeframe. The observations made on these flights will be used to evaluate the moisture, dry static energy and mass budgets by estimating the changes in these parameters between the upstream Sc region sampled on one flight and the downstream Cu region sampled on the subsequent flights. The synthesis of the observations will provide an observational framework for LES studies that will provide a better understating of cloud system evolution in the trades.

Broader impacts:
The project will develop observing and analysis techniques and strategies that will facilitate the development of future missions aimed at studying boundary layer clouds in remote areas that are not easily reached by other observing platforms. The data sets developed will be useful for evaluating satellite retrieval techniques and for evaluating models and model parameterizations applied to a wide range of scales--microphysical, mesoscale, regional, and global. The educational components of this project will include the training of graduate and undergraduate students on the technical aspects of the data collection processes, flight operations, and the subsequent analysis of data to address key science questions. Further, integration of observations from the project into teaching and learning modules that can be used at both the undergraduate and the graduate level will be developed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A key element of the Earth’s cloud systems is the evolution of boundary layer clouds associated with the flow of air around the subtropical anticyclones that are ever prevalent over the Atlantic and Pacific oceans.  Along the westward and equatorward flow in these systems--the trade winds--the boundary layer clouds transition from solid stratocumulus clouds to broken small cumulus clouds.  Since these types of clouds cover larger areas of the Earth’s oceans, the location and the nature of this transition represents an important control on the energy budgets of these areas. The realistic representation this climatically important transition continues to challenge our capability to accurately estimate changes in climate and local responses to global change.  To address this problem, the Cloud System Evolution in the Trades (CSET) study was designed and implemented to describe and explain the evolution of the boundary layer aerosol, cloud, and thermodynamic structures along the flow within the north-Pacific trade-winds. This study centered on 7 round-trips of the NSF NCAR Gulfstream V (GV) between Sacramento, CA and Kona, Hawaii between 7 July and 9 August 2015.  The GV is a research aircraft developed and supported by the National Science Foundation that was well instrumented to study the meteorological and cloud conditions observed during CSET and included a newly developed cloud radar and a lidar that were used together on the GV with in situ measurements to provide an unprecedented characterization of the aerosol, cloud and precipitation structures of low-level clouds in the study area.   

The CSET observing strategy was to sample aerosol, cloud, and boundary layer properties upwind of the transition zone over the North Pacific and then to resample these areas two days later. The US NOAA Global Forecast System (GFS) provided forecasts that were used to plan the outbound flight to Hawaii and the subsequent inbound flight to California two days later (Fig. 1). The strategy was to measure the cloud systems in the upstream areas of the trade winds and then resample these areas two days later as the air masses moved over warmer water over a distance of about 1500 km (800 nautical miles).  The cloud systems sampled during CSET included solid stratocumulus, stratocumulus infused with smoke from Canadian wildfires, mesoscale cloud-precipitation complexes, and patches of shallow cumuli in very clean environments.

The CSET project made substantial advancements in our characterization of the evolution of cloud systems along the southeast extent of the Pacific anticyclone and demonstrated the utility of the sampling strategy developed for the project using the NSF GV.  These observations provide an unprecedented description of the evolution of cloud, precipitation and aerosol fields in the cloud transition within the easterlies over the northern Pacific.  The CSET observations provide comprehensive case studies and integrated data sets to evaluate and improve process models, forecast models, and climate models to describe and explain cloud system evolution in the trades.  

CSET provided enhanced learning and teaching experiences for the undergraduate and graduate students involved directly in CSET.  These experiences were enabled by the Field Catalog developed by the Earth Observing Laboratory (EOL) of the National Center for Atmospheric Research. The Field Catalog ((http://catalog.eol.ucar.edu/cset) was used extensively for mission planning, real-time access to aircraft observations and satellite products during the missions, and for posting reports of mission planning, operations, and summaries.   A CSET teaching module was developed (https://www.eol.ucar.edu/content/cset-educational-module) that allows students to experience the activities involved in carrying out a major aircraft field deployment like CSET.  The module is designed so that students can experience the types of activities involved in the field program and includes mission planning exercises.  

In summary, CSET made substantial advancements in our characterization of the evolution of cloud systems along the southeast extent of the North Pacific anticyclone.  The cloud radar and lidar remote sensing capabilities on the GV were critical to the success of CSET. They provided a detailed characterization of the structure of both precipitating and non-precipitating clouds and the aerosol distributions above, below and around clouds (Fig. 2). The CSET observations have allowed for the development of a new paradigm of the cloud transformation in the trades (Fig. 3).  The clouds evolve from solid stratocumulus decks, to meso-scale precipitating cloud systems, and eventually to broken cumulus clouds. This paradigm provides a basis for future studies of the cloud evolution in the subtropical regions of the Earth’s oceans. The observational techniques developed and demonstrated using the NSF/NCAR GV research aircraft provide a firm basis for future studies of low-level clouds in other remote areas of the Earth.
